etymologies: 1970s: of uncertain origin. Among various (unsubstantiated) theories, one cites the phrase the full Montague Burton, apparently meaning ‘a complete three-piece suit’ (from the name of a tailor of made-to-measure clothing in the early 20th century); another recounts the possibility of a military usage, the full monty being ‘the full cooked English breakfast’ insisted upon by Field Marshal Montgomery. In full monty (sense 2) the term was popularized by the 1997 film The Full Monty

definitions: the full amount expected, desired, or possible

examples.text: when conducting a funeral he wears the full monty: frock coat, top hat and a Victorian cane

definitions: a striptease performance involving full nudity, especially by a man

examples.text: the famous final scene where the characters do the full monty and strip naked
